description: Borrowed from French ravin (“a gully”), from Old French raviner (“to pillage, sweep down, cascade”), from ravine (“robbery, rapine; violent rush of water, waterfall, avalanche; impetuosity, spirit”), from Latin rapīna (cf. rapine).

entries.meaning: A deep narrow valley or gorge in the earth's surface worn by running water.

description: From Middle English ravene, ravine, from Old French raviner (“rush, seize by force”), itself from ravine (“rapine”), from Latin rapīna (“plundering, loot”), itself from rapere (“seize, plunder, abduct”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) Alternative form of raven (“rapine, rapacity; prey, plunder”)
examples: And he, shall he,Man, her last work, who seem’d so fair, […]Who trusted God was love indeedAnd love Creation’s final law—Tho’ Nature, red in tooth and clawWith ravine, shriek’d against his creed—Who loved, who suffer’d countless ills,Who battled for the True, the Just,Be blown about the desert dust,Or seal’d within the iron hills?
